questions.question: How would you describe your general mood over the past few weeks?

options.option: Mostly happy, content, and calm
Mixed – some good days and some bad
Frequently down, irritable, or upset
Constantly overwhelmed, hopeless, or emotionally numb

questions.question: Do you find it difficult to connect or communicate with people around you (friends, family, co-workers)?

options.option: No, I have strong relationships and communicate easily
Sometimes, but it’s manageable
Yes, I struggle to communicate and connect often
Yes, I feel very isolated and misunderstood, and I avoid social interactions

questions.question: How often do you experience physical symptoms like headaches, tension, or stomach issues due to stress?

options.option: Rarely or never
Occasionally, but I can manage it
Frequently, it affects my daily life
Almost every day, I’m often in pain or discomfort

questions.question: Have you been feeling a lack of motivation or interest in things you once enjoyed (e.g., hobbies, work, social activities)?

options.option: Not at all – I’m still passionate about my interests
Occasionally, but it’s only temporary
Frequently, I’ve lost interest in things
Yes, I’ve completely lost interest in almost everything

questions.question: Do you feel overwhelmed by responsibilities or demands, both at home and work?

options.option: No, I feel I can handle my responsibilities well
Sometimes, but I manage with some effort
Yes, I often feel overwhelmed by what’s expected of me
Yes, I can barely keep up with everything, and it’s affecting my health

questions.question: How do you typically handle conflict or challenging situations in your life?

options.option: Calmly and effectively – I find solutions
I try to handle it, but sometimes get frustrated or anxious
I often feel helpless or avoid conflict
I panic, become angry, or shut down in difficult situations

questions.question: Do you experience any feelings of guilt, shame, or regret that are hard to move past?

options.option: No, I’ve made peace with my past
Sometimes, but I usually work through it
Frequently, I carry guilt or regret from past mistakes
Yes, I’m overwhelmed by guilt or shame that I can't seem to overcome

questions.question: Do you have trouble sleeping (falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early)?

options.option: No, I sleep well and wake up refreshed
Occasionally, but I manage with a good routine
Yes, I have trouble falling or staying asleep regularly
Yes, sleep is a constant struggle, and I often feel exhausted during the day

questions.question: Are you able to handle changes or unexpected events in your life easily?

options.option: Yes, I adapt quickly to changes
Sometimes, I can handle them, but it takes time
I often struggle with change and it stresses me out
I feel lost or overwhelmed by even small changes

questions.question: Do you feel a sense of fulfillment or purpose in your life?

options.option: Yes, I feel fulfilled and have a clear sense of purpose
Occasionally, I feel purpose, but it’s not consistent
I often question my purpose and feel lost
No, I don’t feel like I have any sense of purpose or direction

questions.question: How do you feel about your relationships with close family members (parents, spouse, children)?

options.option: Strong and supportive relationships
Sometimes strained, but overall okay
Strained or distant most of the time
Conflict and tension are frequent, and the relationships are unhealthy

questions.question: Do you often feel anxious or worried about future events, even when things are going well?

options.option: Not at all – I generally feel calm about the future
Occasionally, but it’s manageable
Frequently, I worry about what’s ahead
Yes, I often feel an overwhelming sense of anxiety about what’s coming

questions.question: How would you describe your self-esteem or self-worth?

options.option: I feel confident and positive about myself
I have some doubts, but overall I feel okay about who I am
I often feel inadequate or not good enough
I feel worthless or struggle with my identity and self-worth

questions.question: Do you feel that you lack emotional support or have difficulty asking for help when you need it?

options.option: No, I have a strong support system and ask for help when needed
Sometimes, but I manage on my own most of the time
Yes, I often feel unsupported and struggle to ask for help
Yes, I feel completely alone and can’t ask for help

questions.question: How often do you spend quality one-on-one time with your child?

options.option: Almost every day, even if it’s just a few minutes.
A few times a week when possible.
Not as often as I’d like.

questions.question: When your child is upset, do you…

options.option: Listen to their feelings and validate their emotions.
Try to fix the problem immediately.
Tell them to stop crying or calm down.

questions.question: How do you manage discipline at home?

options.option: I use positive reinforcement and calm discussions to set expectations.
I mostly react based on the situation.
I tend to be more strict or lenient, depending on the mood.

questions.question: Do you celebrate small victories, like finishing homework or helping with chores?

options.option: Yes, I always celebrate even the small wins to motivate them.
Sometimes, but not always.
I focus more on major achievements like exams or awards.

questions.question: How often do you have 'family time' without any distractions (phones, TV, etc.)?

options.option: At least once a week – usually during meals or games.
Sometimes, but it's hard to find time.
Rarely, there’s always something else to do.

questions.question: When your child makes a mistake, you…

options.option: Discuss what went wrong and how they can learn from it.
Explain the consequences, but don’t focus on the mistake too much.
I get upset and tell them not to repeat it.

questions.question: How do you show your love and affection to your child?

options.option: I hug, praise, and verbally express love regularly.
I do small gestures, like making their favorite food.
I mostly show love through actions like providing for them.

questions.question: How do you approach your child’s academic progress?

options.option: I stay involved and encourage them without stressing.
I make sure they complete their assignments, but I don’t push too hard.
I focus on grades more than their learning process.

questions.question: Do you encourage your child to express their emotions?

options.option: Yes, I create an open space where they feel safe to talk.
Sometimes, but only when they seem really upset.
I usually tell them to keep their emotions in check.

questions.question: How often do you take time for yourself to recharge?

options.option: I try to make time for self-care regularly.
Only when I feel really overwhelmed.
I rarely take time for myself – it's always about the family.

questions.question: How do you react when your partner expresses their feelings or concerns?

options.option: I listen and validate their feelings.
I get defensive and argue.
I ignore them and avoid talking about it.

questions.question: Do you often find yourself questioning or doubting your partner’s actions or intentions without valid reasons?

options.option: No, I trust them completely.
Sometimes, but I try to be rational.
Yes, I constantly worry they’re hiding something.

questions.question: When your partner makes a mistake, how do you react?

options.option: I discuss it calmly and work together to fix it.
I get angry and bring up past mistakes.
I hold it over their head or use it against them.

questions.question: Do you feel like you respect your partner’s space, time, and privacy?

options.option: Yes, we both have our personal space.
I sometimes check in on their activities out of concern.
I feel the need to know everything they’re doing, where they are, and who they’re with.

questions.question: How often do you criticize your partner’s actions or decisions?

options.option: Rarely, I try to support them.
Occasionally, but I try to be constructive.
Frequently, I believe it’s my job to point out their flaws.

questions.question: When disagreements arise, how do you handle them?

options.option: We talk it out calmly and try to understand each other.
We argue, and things get heated.
I shut down or try to win the argument at all costs.

questions.question: Do you find yourself comparing your partner to others (exes, friends, celebrities)?

options.option: No, I love them for who they are.
Sometimes, but I don’t let it affect the relationship.
Yes, often, and it makes me feel disappointed in them.

questions.question: Do you ever belittle or mock your partner in private or in front of others?

options.option: Never, I respect and uplift them.
Occasionally, I make jokes but they know it's all in fun.
Yes, sometimes I make remarks that are meant to hurt or embarrass them.

questions.question: How do you handle your partner’s success or achievements?

options.option: I celebrate their success and feel happy for them.
I feel proud but sometimes a bit jealous.
I downplay their achievements or try to overshadow them.

questions.question: When your partner expresses an opinion or belief that differs from yours, how do you respond?

options.option: I listen and respect their perspective.
I try to convince them that I’m right.
I dismiss their opinions and try to change their mind.

questions.question: Do you feel that your partner often has to "walk on eggshells" around you?

options.option: No, we are comfortable and open with each other.
Sometimes, depending on the situation.
Yes, they are often cautious about what they say or do around me.

questions.question: How do you handle jealousy or insecurity in the relationship?

options.option: I communicate openly with my partner about my feelings.
I keep it to myself but feel uncomfortable.
I become possessive and act out.

questions.question: When your partner is upset, do you offer comfort or try to "fix" them?

options.option: I listen and offer support without trying to fix them.
I try to give advice and make them feel better quickly.
I avoid them or try to downplay their feelings.

questions.question: How do you feel about your partner spending time with friends or alone?

options.option: I encourage them to have time for themselves or with friends.
I feel a bit left out but try to let them have their space.
I get upset and want them to spend all their time with me.

questions.question: Do you ever gaslight your partner (denying things that happened or making them question their reality)?

options.option: Never, I am open and honest.
Sometimes, I can be defensive or misinterpret things.
Yes, I’ve done it to avoid responsibility or make them feel confused.

questions.question: Do you often dismiss your partner's feelings or concerns?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you get angry or upset over small things your partner does?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you try to control where your partner goes or who they talk to?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you blame your partner for things that go wrong in your life?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you find it hard to apologize, even when you know you’re in the wrong?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you use guilt or manipulation to get your partner to do things?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you ignore your partner’s needs because you’re too focused on your own comfort?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you make fun of your partner's appearance or actions in a hurtful way?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you take your partner for granted, thinking they’ll always be there for you?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you avoid tough conversations, even when they’re necessary?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you struggle to meet your partner halfway during disagreements?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you belittle your partner’s ideas or achievements?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you act passive-aggressive when you're upset with your partner?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you struggle to trust your partner, even when they’ve earned it?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Do you often ignore your partner’s need for alone time or personal space?

options.option: Always
Sometimes
Rarely
Never

questions.question: Have you been feeling more irritable or angry than usual?

questions.question: Do you ever feel like life isn’t worth living, even though you’re trying to push those thoughts away?

options.option: Always
Sometimes

questions.question: Do you often replay conversations in your head, wondering if you said the wrong thing?

options.option: Not really.
Occasionally, but I try not to.
Yes, all the time!

questions.question: When making decisions, do you second-guess yourself endlessly?

options.option: I usually decide quickly and stick with it.
Sometimes, but I get over it.
Yes, I can’t make a decision without a lot of doubt.

questions.question: Do you constantly worry about future events that may or may not happen?

options.option: Not really, I try to live in the moment.
Sometimes, but I try to focus on the present.
Yes, I always imagine the worst-case scenario.

questions.question: Do you find it difficult to focus on a task because your mind keeps wandering to other things?

options.option: I’m usually pretty focused.
Occasionally, but I can usually refocus.
Yes, all the time!

questions.question: Do you analyze every little detail about your personal interactions (e.g., texts, body language, tone)?

options.option: Not at all, I don’t stress over details.
Sometimes, but I try to let it go.
Yes, it’s exhausting!

questions.question: Do you avoid taking action because you're too busy overthinking potential outcomes?

options.option: I’m pretty quick to act on things.
Sometimes, but I eventually take action.
Yes, I often procrastinate because of my thoughts.

questions.question: When faced with a problem, do you obsess over possible solutions for hours (or days)?

options.option: I usually solve problems fairly quickly.
Occasionally, but I don’t let it control me.
Yes, I can’t stop thinking about all the possibilities.

questions.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed by the number of thoughts constantly running through your head?

options.option: Not really, I manage to quiet my mind.
Sometimes, but I find ways to calm myself down.
Yes, it feels like my brain never stops.

questions.question: When making a choice, do you always worry about what others will think?

options.option: Not really, I make decisions based on what feels right for me.
Sometimes, but I try not to let it dictate my decisions.
Yes, I worry about everyone’s opinion.

questions.question: Do you ever find yourself stuck in an endless loop of thoughts that lead to nothing?

options.option: Not really, I usually know when to stop thinking.
Sometimes, but I can snap out of it.
Yes, I keep thinking in circles with no solution.

questions.question: Do you feel like your overthinking is impacting your relationships or work?

options.option: Not really, I don’t think it affects much.
Sometimes, but I manage to work through it.
Yes, it’s definitely causing problems.

questions.question: Do you find it hard to relax or turn off your brain, even during downtime?

options.option: Not really, I can unwind easily.
Sometimes, but I can relax if I try.
Yes, my brain is always active.

questions.question: Do you often seek reassurance from others to calm your doubts?

options.option: Not really, I trust my own instincts.
Occasionally, but I try to trust my own judgment.
Yes, I need constant validation.

questions.question: Do you catch yourself creating 'what if' scenarios that don’t actually happen?

options.option: Not really, I’m pretty realistic.
Sometimes, but I try to stop myself.
Yes, all the time! I make up stories in my head.

questions.question: When something goes wrong, do you dwell on it for longer than necessary?

options.option: Not really, I let go of things easily.
Sometimes, but I try to move on.
Yes, I can’t let it go.

questions.question: Do you say “yes” to things you don’t want to do just to avoid disappointing others?

options.option: Yes, all the time!
Sometimes, but I try to stand up for myself.
Rarely, I try to say “no” when needed.

questions.question: Do you often put others' needs before your own, even when you're exhausted?

options.option: Yes, I often do this, even if it means sacrificing my own well-being.
Sometimes, but I try to take care of myself too.
No, I usually make time for myself.

questions.question: Do you feel guilty when you need to say 'no' or set boundaries?

options.option: Yes, I feel terrible about it.
Sometimes, but I know it’s necessary.
Not really, I try to set boundaries confidently.

questions.question: Do you avoid conflicts at all costs, even if it means suppressing your own feelings?

options.option: Yes, I hate conflict and will do anything to keep the peace.
Sometimes, but I try to express myself when it’s important.
Not at all, I don’t mind healthy conflict.

questions.question: Do you often worry about what others think of you, even after they’ve stopped thinking about it?

options.option: Yes, I replay situations in my head, wondering if I did something wrong.
Sometimes, but I try not to overthink it.
No, I don’t care what others think.

questions.question: Do you frequently apologize, even when you haven’t done anything wrong?

options.option: Yes, I’m always apologizing, even when I don’t need to.
Sometimes, but I try to be more mindful of it.
No, I don’t apologize unless I truly need to.

questions.question: Do you feel responsible for making others happy, even if it means sacrificing your own happiness?

options.option: Yes, I often feel like it’s my job to make others happy.
Sometimes, but I try to balance it out.
Not really, I focus on my own happiness too.

questions.question: When someone asks for your help, do you agree right away, even if it causes stress or overload?

options.option: Yes, I feel like I can’t say no.
Sometimes, but I try to assess if I have the time.
No, I make sure I can handle it before agreeing.

questions.question: Do you often feel like you're walking on eggshells to avoid upsetting anyone?

options.option: Yes, I’m always worried about offending people.
Sometimes, but I’ve learned to express myself more openly.
No, I speak my mind without fear.

questions.question: Do you feel uncomfortable when people are upset with you, even if it's not your fault?

options.option: Yes, I take it personally and feel anxious about it.
Sometimes, but I try to remind myself it’s not always my fault.
Not at all, I don’t let it bother me much.

questions.question: Do you avoid asking for help, even when you’re struggling, because you don’t want to burden anyone?

options.option: Yes, I’d rather figure things out on my own.
Sometimes, but I do ask for help when I really need it.
No, I’m comfortable asking for help when necessary.

questions.question: Do you feel like you lose a part of yourself in relationships because you’re too focused on others?

options.option: Yes, I often feel like I’ve lost my identity.
Sometimes, but I try to stay true to myself.
Not really, I keep a good balance.

questions.question: When you receive a compliment, do you downplay it or deflect it because you feel unworthy of praise?

options.option: Yes, I rarely accept compliments.
Sometimes, but I try to acknowledge them.
No, I accept compliments gracefully.

questions.question: Do you tend to agree with others’ opinions or ideas, even if you secretly disagree?

options.option: Yes, I don’t like to rock the boat.
Sometimes, but I voice my opinion when it’s important.
Not at all, I express my own thoughts.

questions.question: Do you feel like you're constantly trying to please others but still feel unappreciated?

options.option: Yes, I often feel like no one notices all I do for them.
Sometimes, but I try to remind myself of my value.
No, I feel appreciated for what I do.

questions.question: When you feel down, what helps you the most?

options.option: A long hug or cuddle.
Someone surprising me with a thoughtful gift.
Having a deep conversation about how I feel.
A heartfelt note or text message.

questions.question: How do you prefer to show affection to your partner?

options.option: Physical touch, like holding hands or hugging.
Buying thoughtful gifts that show I care.
Talking openly about how I feel about them.
Writing them sweet notes or texting them throughout the day.

questions.question: When you're in a fight with your partner, what do you crave the most?

options.option: Physical comfort, like a hug or holding hands.
A surprise gift or gesture to lighten the mood.
A calm and understanding conversation.
A message or note that expresses how they feel about you.

questions.question: If you could spend your ideal day with your partner, what would you want to do?

options.option: Spend time being close—cuddling on the couch or holding hands while walking.
Go shopping or explore a new store together, picking out something special for each other.
Have a deep, meaningful conversation over coffee or dinner.
Write or exchange love notes and sweet texts throughout the day.

questions.question: How do you feel about public displays of affection?

options.option: I love holding hands or hugging in public.
I like surprising my partner with little gifts in public.
I prefer meaningful conversations or sharing intimate moments in private.
I enjoy receiving or giving sweet texts when we're apart.

questions.question: How do you feel about gifts?

options.option: Gifts are nice, but I prefer affection and time together.
I love receiving thoughtful gifts—they mean a lot to me.
Gifts aren’t as important as emotional connection.
I like when my partner writes me heartfelt messages or letters.

questions.question: What's your idea of a romantic gesture?

options.option: A spontaneous kiss or cuddle.
A surprise gift, especially one that shows thoughtfulness.
A heart-to-heart talk where we share our feelings openly.
A handwritten letter or a sweet text telling me how they feel.

questions.question: When your partner is having a tough day, what do you do?

options.option: Give them a comforting hug and sit with them.
Surprise them with their favorite treat or gift.
Sit down and have a deep conversation about what’s bothering them.
Text them something sweet or leave them a note to brighten their day.

questions.question: How do you like to receive compliments?

options.option: I love it when someone expresses their affection through physical gestures.
I feel appreciated when I get compliments, especially with little gifts.
Compliments mean a lot, especially when they’re about how I feel or what I think.
Compliments in writing, whether in notes or texts, really make my day.

questions.question: When you think about a perfect evening together, what do you envision?

options.option: Relaxing together, maybe cuddling or holding hands while watching a movie.
Doing something fun together, like shopping, or exchanging gifts.
Talking about life, feelings, and dreams over dinner.
Sending sweet messages to each other throughout the night.

questions.question: How do you prefer to receive affection when you’re feeling low?

options.option: I need a hug or physical affection to feel better.
A small, thoughtful gift or gesture makes me feel loved.
I appreciate deep conversations that help me process my emotions.
A sweet message, text, or letter expressing affection means a lot to me.

questions.question: How do you like to express love to your partner?

options.option: Through physical touch—holding hands, cuddling, etc.
By surprising them with thoughtful gifts or gestures.
By opening up and sharing my feelings with them.
Through written words—cards, notes, or messages.

questions.question: When your partner is excited about something, how do you show you care?

options.option: Give them a hug or a high-five.
Surprise them with a thoughtful gift to celebrate.
Have an in-depth conversation with them about what excites them.
Send them a quick text to let them know you’re happy for them.

questions.question: What’s your ideal form of communication with your partner?

options.option: Face-to-face, with lots of physical touch.
Giving and receiving gifts to show care.
Sitting down to talk about how we feel.
Writing letters or sending thoughtful texts.
